thread.title: British food icon Anchor Cheddar is to disappear from supermarket shelves
thread.title_full: British food icon Anchor Cheddar is to disappear from supermarket shelves

author: Karen Rockett
title: British food icon Anchor Cheddar is to disappear from supermarket shelves
text:
News British food icon Anchor Cheddar is to disappear from supermarket shelves Cheese brand, originally launched in 1972, has lost ground to Cathedral City and Pilgrims Choice despite a £6m ad campaign Share Anchor Cheddar was launched in 1972 but is being abandoned by supermarkets (Photo: Arla) Share Get daily     
Anchor Cheddar cheese is about to vanish from ­ supermarket shelves. 
Asda has become the last major retailer to drop it and is selling its remaining stock. 
Despite a £6million ­advertising campaign in 2015, sales for the brand fell 63 per cent last year – from £28million down to £10.2million. 
The cheese, made by Arla and relaunched in 2013, is said to have failed to break the dominance of Cathedral City and Pilgrims Choice. 
Trade magazine The Grocer said that Anchor has been the main victim of a major cull of Cheddar brands over the past two years as retailers simplify their offerings with a greater focus on own-label Cheddar alongside a market leader and secondary brand. Read More Why Domino's costs so much in the UK – when a large pizza costs £3 in other countries Rival cheese firms and supermarket own brands have made things tough for Anchor (Photo: Getty) 
Anchor Cheddar was launched in 1972 by New Zealand-owned Anchor butter. Arla took it over in 2001, dumped it in 2008 and started it up again in 2013. Like us on Facebook
